Message.Title: The 'cult of capitalism' and U.S. moral decline
Message.Msg: The 'cult of capitalism' and U.S. moral decline Today 5:00 AM ET (MarketWatch)Print Capitalism is now a cult, and Jamie Dimon is the self-appointed leader of the "cult of capitalism." That message is gleaned from a Huffington Post column by Mark Gongloff, whose headline stated that not only is the J.P. Morgan CEO and chairman a cult leader but a "very dangerous" one. Why? Because apparently shareholders have signed "a billion-year contract" to join the cult, notwithstanding portrayals of Dimon as a greedy egomaniac and poster boy for everything wrong with capitalism. His is a monster of a cult: Warren Buffett is a member. So is CNBC's Jim Cramer. Says Gongloff, who labels Cramer a "shouty man": "Cramer joined Warren Buffett and many more VIPs in singing Dimon's praises and warning of the woe that would befall shareholders" if they split his roles. Still, "the media played along, helping ... Dimon keep both of his jobs" as J.P. Morgan Chase & Co.'s chief executive and chairman. Dimon, meanwhile, was doing what any self-respecting egomaniac under such a threat would do: acting like a petulant teenager and threatening to quit. Today, reconfirmed as leader of the cult of capitalism, Dimon could serve as the perfect example of what psychologist Ernest Becker wrote about in his Pulitzer Prize–winning classic, "The Denial of Death," a favorite from my years at Morgan Stanley. Dimon fits the cult-leader profile: charismatic narcissist, uncompromising, manipulating and threatening to his co-conspirators in the "cult of capitalism" and to the masses marching to the drumbeat of his destiny, off another economic cliff, bigger than 2008's. The destiny of this cult of capitalism is also driven by historical trends that Dimon cannot see, trends beyond his control, beyond his leadership talents. Why? He is blinded, incapable of seeing the mega-billion-dollar danger Gongloff claims to have spotted dead ahead. Is the new capitalism is destroying America's morals?

Topic.Title: The 'cult of capitalism' and U.S. moral decline

Message.Msg: Your caricature of Dimon is too simplistic and to call him a "monster of a cult" is at best bizarre. Most people on this forum have no idea about what capitalism is or its origins and dependencies in the 20th century USA. They don't realize that the USA was founded as a mercantile nation, as is plainly evidenced in our constitution's dependence on tariffs until the enactment of the Income Tax amendment. And they don't realize that our economy is not a pure capitalism but a mix of socialism and capitalism, as is virtually all modern economies are. Until posters can frame their comments or questions with respect to those factors, they can only post nonsense. Dimon is a clever, suave CEO but trying to turn him into a target simply shows that any disagreement with him is a personal disagreement that has nothing to do with capitalism or its limits. Of course the trends are beyond his control. He knows that. Dooms day sayers like Gongloff are a waste of time and only attract people looking for easy, tiny answers to fit in their small minds. As for morals, they are innate and you can neither increase them nor decrease them because they are an evolutionary byproduct of our being social animals. Finally, do we have problems to solve? When have we ever not had problems to solve?

Topic.Title: The 'cult of capitalism' and U.S. moral decline

Message.Msg: You have several wild assumptions in your post. It is impossible to place a percentage of what is capitalism or socialism in any economy because they are mutually intertwined and supportive of each other. The myth is that capitalism and socialism are mutually exclusive or antagonistic with each other. Just the opposite is true. Capitalism without our mix with socialism would cannibalize the workers that are the dynamic engine of capitalism. Socialism without capitalism would lead to lower productivity and a lack of incentive. As for Steve Jobs, it is amazing that you can read the mind of a dead entrepreneur. But Steve, in a commencement address at Stanford in 2005 did not mention the desire to get rich as his motivation. Instead he recounted his learning calligraphy and a sense of aesthetics as what motivated him to produce devices that were intuitive and people loved to have and use. Socialism is dead? You are selectively blind to a remarkable part of the economies of every modern industrial nation. I guess you are one of the Tea Party ignoramuses who don't know the difference between modern socialism in its integration with capitalism and communism, which is dead, or even socialism of 100 years ago. Please update your McGuffy readers.

Message.Title: BAC abd other money center banks up today on sector rotation
Message.Msg: Money is flowing out of big pharma, utilities, transports and others into large money center banks, promarily due to the growth that is seen in this sector caused by rising interest rates. As rates rise so does the net interest margin.

Topic.Title: BAC abd other money center banks up today on sector rotation

Message.Msg: Actually, it is declining rates that are more favorable, initially, to banks. Banks carry a lot of fixed rate loans on their books. As the rates they have to pay to borrow money, and to pay on deposits, that actually squeezes margins. Over time, banks profit from higher rates, but if rates go up to fast banks can be severely squeezed as it takes time for them to rotate their loan books to the higher rates.

Topic.Title: The 'cult of capitalism' and U.S. moral decline

Message.Msg: from what I can tell, the current strategy is to have money trickle down through banks as ben buys mortgages. Unfortunately this does not seem to be causing anyone toput value into this new money by producting, just feeling more confident and consuming. You seem to equate confidence and asset prices with goodness, is this the way alexis thinks? Eventually these highly valued assets will need to be consumed, homes just from wear and tear and maintenance costs, things like stocks sold to someone else plus any dividents that reflect real profits. You can already see signs that this circle jerk is not as good as the prior Bush version, the jobs being created don't seem to pay as much for example. The real issues are things like availability of food and shelter. It does seem that more "poor" people are able to occupy suburban homes, so in fact this may be a good sign as long as good and utilities are paid for. However, the food supply could again become a question. more spending, more undoing, that's the power of the economic circle jerk. ROFLMFO. I'm also concerned about kingofvietnam's mental state, tan lines would have been fine but he seems a bit obsessed. ROFLMFO. It would be interesting to see what his social media pages look like.
